Typography

The application, and this website, use the Inter typeface family, which is open-source and also supports the â‚¿ unicode character.

Text styles

    Inter Semi-Bold 36/44

    A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System

  2. Header 2

    Inter Semi-Bold 28/34

    A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System

    Inter Semi-Bold 21/25

    A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System

  5. Header 5

    Inter Semi-Bold 18/21

    A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System

  6. Header 6

    Inter Semi-Bold 15/18

    A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System

  7. Body 1

    Inter Regular 24/36

    A purely peer-to-peer version of electronic cash would allow online payments to be sent directly from one party to another without going through a financial institution. Digital signatures provide part of the solution, but the main benefits are lost if a trusted third party is still required to prevent double-spending.

  8. Body 2

    Inter Regular 21/31

    A purely peer-to-peer version of electronic cash would allow online payments to be sent directly from one party to another without going through a financial institution. Digital signatures provide part of the solution, but the main benefits are lost if a trusted third party is still required to prevent double-spending.

  9. Body 3

    Inter Regular 18/27

    A purely peer-to-peer version of electronic cash would allow online payments to be sent directly from one party to another without going through a financial institution. Digital signatures provide part of the solution, but the main benefits are lost if a trusted third party is still required to prevent double-spending.

  10. Body 4

    Inter Regular 15/22

    A purely peer-to-peer version of electronic cash would allow online payments to be sent directly from one party to another without going through a financial institution. Digital signatures provide part of the solution, but the main benefits are lost if a trusted third party is still required to prevent double-spending.

  11. Body 5

    Inter Regular 13/19

    A purely peer-to-peer version of electronic cash would allow online payments to be sent directly from one party to another without going through a financial institution. Digital signatures provide part of the solution, but the main benefits are lost if a trusted third party is still required to prevent double-spending.
